p: The vast majority of studies reported CHIKV testing on blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF); S2 Table. Uncommon samples that were successfully tested for CHIKV included corneas [ 66], oral secretions [ 67– 69], peritoneal, gastric and blister fluids [ 70– 73], urine and semen [ 74]. Saliva was found to be useful in molecular testing only for a week post symptom onset and was reported to be less sensitive than blood samples in one study [ 69]. Another study reported identifying viable virus in urine and semen samples even up to 30 days post infection [ 74].
